column11: Review Text

Must, must do! Just must do. The Baker's fall are a part of The Horton Plains National park which is one of the most beautiful locations in Sri Lanka. It is a 9km circle which has three stops along the way – Mini World’s End, World’s End and Baker’s Fall. The trail is easy (will short patches of incline along the way which are easy to climb) and breathtakingly beautiful. Finish it off with a cup of tea and biscuits at the canteen overlooking the plains. On more practical information, the entrance to the plains is an hour’s drive from Nuwara Elliya (approximately) and the tickets are slightly expensive (but worth every penny). Take the route on the left (which reaches baker’s fall last) since it’s a better way to circle the plains. Also, if you get tired halfway and feel the urge to turn back – don’t, because even if you turn back you’ll have the same distance to cover and you’ll miss the trail on the other side.
I am fascinated with waterfalls and I like to hear the thunder sound of water. It is a nice spot of taking loverly photos.

We visited as part of our walk in the park. There is a steep but not to arduous path down to them. Perhaps, as it was out of the rainy season, the true spectacle was not evident. I however found them average and not a patch on others I have seen in the world. That said they are worth a detour on the walk.

This Fall is comparatively smaller but it has its own charm and uniqueness. It's beautiful and the water flow is strong. Though you can't spend a lot of time admiring it as other hikers are waiting for their turn to appreciate this natural beauty. Photos don't do justice to this beauty.
Its an OK attraction. Waterfall is quite small and when we went the platform was quite crowded. Would go to HP for the trekking not so much to see this
Another great waterfall to be seen after trekking the worlds end. A beautiful place for photography and one should not miss this at all..
Important place to visit in Horton Plains National park. most people are visit on this last of the walk. but we saw this first. that side the best.
While the falls are a short hike off the trail down some rather steep steps, they are certainly worth the walk. I was there in dry season and the falls were still impressive!
it was so refreshing to see bakers fall after the long world's end trek.  though the water was too cold to take a dip, sitting besides it was equally soothing
Walk around 7 kms through the Horton plains national park, you will find Baker falls... Safe stairs are there for going down. Going with children seems difficult.
You reach there after a long walk in Horton Plains, very relaxing place with the sound of the fall gashing down,  before continue your walk to world end.. enjoy
During your trip in the park you reach this waterfall. It is a nice waterfall and a perfect place to take a little rest. If you walk the whole tour it takes about 5 hours of walking.

wide water fall of about 20 m in height and about 25 m in width was named after a famous British Hunter in Horton Planes. From entrance via Chimney-pool it takes about 1 hour to reach there. The falls plays a major role for the vegetation and special species of fauna around there, by producing moisture rich environment. One of the remarkable plant there is "Nelu" (Strobilanthes sp.), an endemic plant which bear flowers once in life time after it grows 8 or 9 years. One of the Reptile highly highlighted is Sri Lanka Pygmy Lizard (cophotis ceylanica)
A very nice waterfall at the Horton Plains National Park. You will find it when you do the complete walk of around 8-9 kilometers.

Its 40 km from Bandarawela or 30 km from Diyatalawa or 35 km from Nuwaraeliya. When you reach Pattipola you have to walk another 4 km to reach this picturesque waterfall. It s 22 meters in height. Taking photographs over there is very difficult. Be careful with your life. If you slip you will fall down with deadly injuries. Take care.
Great waterfall, a peacful place where you can only hear the sound of water. Managed to take great pictures here.

Waterfalls are waterfalls. No matter what the height is, or what the width is... waterfalls make you freshen up in a moment and bring back that energy the Sun sapped away! Part of the Horton Plains 9+km trail, I went to the Baker's Falls towards the end. An easy climb down and a challenging climb up, its all worth it. For the more adventurous, do what I did - hop down through the back onto the rocks and touch the ice cold waters! :)
A nice waterfall, and part of the Horton Plains circuit walk. Good viewing platform. It can be rather slippery getting to the falls as you walk through forest, so wear good shoes.
The waterfalls are very nice...the climb down to see them requires a somewhat challenging climb up to return to the trail!
Along the World's End Trail. Nice stop, nice photo op. But waterfalls are waterfalls. This isn't Vic Falls or Angel Falls.

The falls are worth visiting along the Trek in the Horton National Park But they clerly need to make a better access as the stairs leading down to the falls are so big even for a tall person like me specially when they charge you so much for the entrace fees

Situated within the Horton Plains National Park this is a very beautiful sight. Any traveler would like to stay for a while near the Bakers falls just to observe the beauty of it. Amazing what nature could give us.

This a not a big fall, but a nice break during your Horton Plains hike to admire the water and perhaps fuel up if you have not had the chance to do so before you continue the rest of the way. Keep your hands free to help you grip the branches as you climb up and down to get to the falls. Skip this part if it is raining and slippery. Don't attempt this carrying your child.

The road leading to the fall is of a damp road  specially if your’ going on a rainy day(which we went), and it best advice to go thier in the morning or afternoon  and not in the evening , cause when you return from their if it’s dark you’ll have a difficult time getting back(which happened to us) Visiting this place is not advisable if you’re travelling with small children other than that the “bakers fall” is not a very huge waterfall but a normal one

Baker's Falls is inside the Horton Plains National Park. The height of the waterfall is 20 metres (66 ft) and named after Sir Samuel Baker, the famous British explorer, officer, naturalist, big game hunter, engineer, writer and abolitionist.who discovered the falls in 1845. It is known for the tremendous noise created by the water pounding the large rock formation at its foot. Baker is also known for shooting 50 elephants, five deer and two buffalos nearby! The falls, and the 12m death trap of a plunge pool, has claimed numerous lives of reckless tourists.
